title: Hirschsprung’s Disease
diagnosis_topic: Congenital aganglionosis causing functional intestinal obstruction
setup_script: “A term newborn fails to pass meconium within 48 hours of birth. The infant has progressive abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. There is no family history of gastrointestinal disease. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: HR 150 bpm, RR 50/min, Temp 37 °C; mildly tachycardic.
Distended abdomen with palpable intestinal loops; explosive passage of stool following digital rectal exam.
Dilated bowel loops with air–fluid levels; absence of gas in distal rectum.
Transition zone between dilated proximal colon and narrow distal aganglionic segment.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident arranges rectal suction biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: Histology shows absence of ganglion cells confirming Hirschsprung’s disease.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates decompression with rectal irrigations and keeps NPO
dynamic_flow.reply: Decompression relieves distension; broad-spectrum antibiotics started if enterocolitis suspected.
Risk of enterocolitis, sepsis and perforation increases. Infant becomes febrile and lethargic with worsening abdominal distension.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recognizes deterioration and escalates care
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is stabilized with IV fluids, rectal irrigations, and antibiotics.
Options include staged approach with diverting colostomy followed by pull-through procedure, or primary pull-through depending on stability.
Mobilization of colon, resection of aganglionic segment, and pull-through of ganglionic colon to the anus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: Notes possibility of Down syndrome, congenital heart disease, and genitourinary anomalies.
Monitor for anastomotic leak, stricture, constipation, enterocolitis, and adequate weight gain.
Possible issues include constipation, incontinence, and recurrent enterocolitis; requires ongoing follow-up.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates parents about colostomy care
dynamic_flow.reply: Provides instructions for stoma care and signs of complications.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of delayed meconium passage and suspicion for Hirschsprung’s disease
Use of contrast enema and rectal biopsy to confirm diagnosis
Initial decompression and management of enterocolitis
Surgical planning for pull-through procedure with or without diversion
Postoperative follow-up and management of long-term sequelae
